caseTitle: EMMANUEL ROCKSON v ILIOS SHIPPING COMPANY S.A. AND WILTEX
summary: In Emmanuel Rockson v Ilios Shipping Company S.A. and Wiltex Ltd., the plaintiff, a Ghanaian mariner, sustained injuries while working aboard the M/V Dynamic, a vessel owned by the first defendant and sailing under a Cyprus flag. He filed a writ at the High Court, Sekondi, seeking compensation under a collective insurance policy and 35% interest on the sum due. However, the writ did not disclose a cause of action, containing only a claim for relief without stating the legal basis. The defendants challenged the action on multiple grounds, including lack of jurisdiction and res judicata, but the Supreme Court focused on the fatal defect in the writ. Relying on Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit [2003-2004] SCGLR 689, the Court held that a writ not endorsed with a cause of action is a nullity under Order 2 Rule 1 of the High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules 1954. Despite the plaintiff's supplementary submissions asserting a workmen's compensation claim, he failed to address the jurisdictional defect. The appeal was dismissed solely on this ground, without reaching the merits of the case.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed due to the nullity of the writ of summons for failure to disclose a cause of action.
citations: Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit (Darya Shipping SA Interested Party) [2003-2004] SCGLR 689
Okofoh Estates v Modern Signs Ltd. [1996-97] SCGLR 224
rationaleHighlights: The writ of summons was a nullity because it failed to disclose a cause of action as required by Order 2 Rule 1 of the High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules 1954.

The Supreme Court relied on Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit [2003-2004] SCGLR 689, which established that a writ not endorsed with a substantive claim is a legal nullity.
The appeal was dismissed without addressing other grounds because the foundational writ was invalid.
The plaintiff's attempt to base jurisdiction on insurance claims did not cure the defect in the writ.
Pending motions to amend the writ were not sufficient to validate an otherwise defective writ.
